::: {.unit-reading}
# Reading

## Installing Julia 

Julia provides preâ€‘built binaries for Windows, macOS, and Linux that you can [download from the official website](https://julialang.org/install/). The best option is to use `juliaup` to download and install the latest version. You should be able to install Julia without needing administrative provileges. 

## Starting Julia 

After installation, open a terminal (PowerShell on Windows or a shell on Unixâ€‘like systems) and type `julia`. If the install worked, this should start Julia. You will be in what is called the [Julia REPL (Readâ€“Evalâ€“Print Loop)](https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/stdlib/REPL/). You can type commands into the REPL, though most of the time you will use a script file (we'll discuss that shortly).


## Exploring Julia 

You should see a banner displaying the version number. Type `versioninfo()` into the Julia command prompt for a more detailed report on your platform and linked libraries. If you type `2+2`, you should get `4` as an answer. 

Once you finished playing around, you can exit Julia by typing `exit()` and then closing the terminal.

We'll explore a bit more about Julia in a subsequent unit.

If you got that far, it means your Julia installation is working! If not, search for whatever error message you get, there should be plenty of helpful information online to ensure you can get Julia up and running.


## Julia and Editors

Typing code into the REPL is rarely used for actual work. The standard setup is to instead use an editor to write a Julia script and then execute that script. There are several editors that are frequently used with Julia. For QSPL, we are focusing on Positron, and we'll discuss Julia + Positron in a subsequent unit. Other popular editors are VS Code (on which Positron is based) and Jupyter Notebooks. We won't discuss those here, but if you have a preferred editor that you want to use, you'll likely find some information online on how to set it up for Julia.
